frameDefinitions: One phenomenon, the Predictive_phenomenon is an indication of the future or current (but still uncertain) existence of another phenomenon, the Future_phenomenon.
A Stimulus inspires a feeling of awe and interest in a (generally implicit or generic) Experiencer due to desirable qualities which are difficult to explain.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
A Defendant is tried by a Jury or Judge in a Court for Charges.
A Speaker states or makes known a future Eventuality on the basis of some Evidence.
A Protagonist delays a planned action because they cannot or do not want to proceed until an Expected_event occurs.
frameExamples: There is a certain <t>je-ne-sais-quoi</t> about that city .
The state will <t>try</t> him for fraud.
The Weather Centre <t>predicted</t> that it would be warmer but wet for the weekend.
The cat <t>waited</t> on top of the washer as Elmer popped the lid off the can of cat food and then pounded the can's contents onto the plate
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Predictive_phenomenon</fen> provides evidence for the existence or the nature of the <fen>Outcome</fen> of <fen>Future_phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Future_phenomenon</fen> is that phenomenon that is predicted to occur or have a particular quality.
The role <fen>Outcome</fen> identifies those expressions that indicate how the <fen>Future_phenomenon</fen> is expected to turn out based on the evidence of the <fen>Predictive_phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the omen is occuring.
The location where something good or bad might occur.
The entity which inspires a feeling of amazement at its exceptionality.
An expression of the attribute of ineffability.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Judge</fen> heads the <fen>Court</fen> where the case is tried.  An expression referring to the <fen>Court</fen> may also stand in for the <fen>Judge</fen>.
The <fen>Defendant</fen> is being tried for the <fen>Charges</fen> in <fen>Court</fen>.

This role identifies the people who are charged by the <fen>Court</fen> to listen to the testimony, evidence, and arguments, and come to a consensus about the guilt or innocence of the <fen>Defendant</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Charges</fen> brought against the <fen>Defendant</fen>.
The <fen>Defendant</fen> is tried under the laws of the <fen>Governing_authority</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the case is tried.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the case is tried.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> makes a prediction.

This role marks expressions that indicate an event or state that is predicted to occur or hold at a future time. A single <fen>Eventuality</fen> may be expressed discontinuously in a raising construction. This role is also used for expressions that denote entities with variable attributes about which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes predictions.
The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the prediction.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the prediction pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by <m>about</m>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the prediction is made.
The <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the prediction.
The sentient being who cannot proceed with their planned activities until a Salient_entity has arrived or an Expected_event has occurred.
A concrete or abstract entity that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> expects to participate in an <fen>Expected_event</fen>, typically that of arriving at the <fen>Place</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Expected_event</fen> is an event that needs to take place or a state that needs to begin to hold before the <fen>Protagonist</fen> can proceed with their planned activities.
The time period during which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
The location in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
listRoleExamples: <fex>To achieve so much this year</fex> augurs well for the future.
This move presages <fex>a freeze on the granting of new concessions</fex>.
It all bodes <fex>well</fex> for the future.
The storm bodes ill for you <fex>here</fex> .
She had a magical <fex>quality</fex> .
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
<fex>Judge Murphy</fex> will try the defendant for murder.
<fex>The United States</fex> will try the accused bomber in a federal courthouse.
<fex>The institute</fex> forecast an increase in leisure spending of 15 per cent.
Predicting <fex>the weather</fex> is risky business.
The events that would occur over the next several years had been predicted <fex>in the Bible</fex>.
John predicted <fex>last year</fex> that he would be finished by October.
Greenman predicted <fex>at a small dinner party</fex> that the market would rise again.
<fex>He</fex> politely waited, hat in hand, until he could speak.
In busier times several passengers are waiting <fex>for the train</fex>.
She did n't wait <fex>for a reply</fex>, but spelled out the answer herself.
At least 17 ships were waiting <fex>yesterday</fex> to come up the river.
Reporters are waiting <fex>outside the State Guesthouse</fex> for the talks to start .

passageCandidateSpans.text: the National Bureau of Economic Research

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the National Bureau of Economic Research
